title: 'Whether they like it or not': Donald Trump's threat to Greenland
text: "We are going to do something on Greenland whether they like it or not. Because if we don't do it, Russia or China will take over Greenland, and we're not going to have Russia or China as a neighbour," Trump told reporters at the White House while meeting with oil company executives.

title: Hollywood-backed Wrexham knocks Premier League side out of FA Cup
text:
Second-tier Wrexham — co-owned by Hollywood A-listers Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney — has defeated Nottingham Forest on penalties to reach the fourth round of the FA Cup.

It is the first time Wrexham has beaten a Premier League side in the FA Cup since 1999.

Reynolds was among the 10,063 spectators attending the match at Wrexham's home ground, Stok Cae Ras, with goalkeeper Arthur Okonkwo proving the hero for the hosts.

Okonkwo saved Forest's fifth penalty by Omari Hutchinson to ensure the win.

The match finished 3-3 after regular and extra time, before Wrexham won 4-3 on penalties.

"It was amazing to win the game in the end. We just have to enjoy the moment," Okonkwo told TNT Sports.

Wrexham's Liberato Cacace and Oliver Rathbone scored in quick succession in the first half, and the home side later looked headed for victory with a 3-1 lead in a breathless second term.

Forest's Callum Hudson-Odoi struck in the 76th and 89th minutes to level scores, but Wrexham prevailed in the shootout after extra time ended without a goal.

Ryan Reynolds was on hand to watch Wrexham defeat Forest. (Getty Images: Carl Recine)

"The lads rallied themselves, and there were a lot of tired legs on both teams," Wrexham manager Phil Parkinson said.

"Credit to both sides for putting on such a good game after such a busy Christmas schedule."

Forest manager Sean Dyche gave a scathing review of his starters.

Wrexham one step closer to ‘impossible dream’ Wrexham, and celebrity owners Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney are a step closer to achieving the goal of reaching the top-flight Premier League.

"The first half was completely unacceptable," Dyche said.

"I let the players know this. Certain individuals certainly know. They will have to look in the mirror."

Wexham's win was another memorable chapter in the rise of the Welsh club, which was bought in 2020 by Reynolds and McElhenney.

They have overseen Wrexham's rapid ascent from non-league football to the second tier in three seasons.

The club sits ninth in the Championship and the victory over Forest was its fifth in a row in all competitions.

Reuters

title: Former helicopter firefighter breaks down gender barriers in WA
text:
The first time Erin Tassell got into a helicopter as a child, she felt no fear.

That feeling continued into adulthood, as she hung out of choppers, longlining above bushfires in Canada's Banff National Park.

She said growing up in a "forestry family", there was no shortage of exposure to the industry.

Emergency response work has been Ms Tassell's calling from an early age. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

"I was going to university and looking for summer work, so I took a job as a seasonal firefighter," Ms Tassell said.

"I think I knew pretty early on that's what I wanted to do, and that's the career I wanted to pursue."

Ms Tassell as a child in a helicopter. (Supplied: Erin Tassell)

Ms Tassell is the first female duty officer at the Department of Biodiversity and Attractions (DBCA).

The role, traditionally held by men, is responsible for leading Western Australia's bushfire management and emergency incident response, leading the charge with bushfires, whale rescues and other major incidents.

One extreme to the other

Originally from Prince George in the Canadian province of British Colombia, Ms Tassell worked as a helicopter-based firefighter before relocating to Australia in 2019.

It wasn't long before she was living in the Kimberley in WA's north.

Ms Tassell has been working in the industry for two decades. (Supplied: Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attraction)

"It was certainly two extremes. I moved from the winter in Canada, where it was very, very cold, to the wet season in the northern parts of Western Australia, where it was very, very hot."

The volunteers risking their lives to keep us safe Volunteer firefighters put their lives on the line for their community, Here's why.

The DBCA manages around 34 million hectares of land and water, in national and marine parks, state forest and other land.

Working for the DBCA as a fire aviation manager, Ms Tassell's role was to manage the suppression of bushfires in WA, in conjunction with the Department of Fire and Emergency Services.

In her new role as state duty officer, which she started in late 2025, she said she managed prescribed burning, bushfire suppression, and other emergencies that arose.

Ms Tassell's work oversees a vast expanse of land. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

"The types of jobs we review are prescribed burns; there could be a call about a potential bushfire that's going on or other types of emergencies like a lost hiker," Ms Tassell said.

" I enjoy the mental challenge that comes with it. It certainly tests a lot of the skills that I have and it's also bringing a lot of skills to my repertoire as well. "

'Take the leap'

While historically, leadership roles in fire and emergency management have been male-dominated, Ms Tassell said there had been growth in the past two decades.

"It's exciting [to be in the role], and I think it's one of those things where the hope is that I'm the first, but certainly there are more to come," she said.

The experienced firefighter looks forward to the "mental challenges" of the new role. (Supplied: Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attraction)

"We need to continue to promote diversity in this space.

"Take the giant leap of faith. It's a great career with lots of opportunity and support to work in land and fire management."

title: A Tasmanian council built a wall. It hasn't gone down well
text:
Human history is littered with the remains of big walls.

China has one. It is quite famous. Germany had one, but they tore it down.

Pink Floyd sang about one, and people liked that a lot.

Now Tasmania's West Coast Council has erected its own entry, but locals are not thrilled.

The wall has prompted criticism and confusion from locals. (Facebook: Jason Hart)

At least 30 metres long and 3 metres tall, residents say it blocks views of Macquarie Harbour, affects traffic and creates safety issues on the wharf.

Its purpose, they say, is unclear, despite a public meeting held by the council in Strahan on Thursday night.

Strahan locals are worried the wall blocks views of the picturesque waterfront. (Supplied: Strahan Village)

Calls to tear down 'Berlin Wall'

The wall runs parallel to the Strahan Esplanade and is part of the council's long-held plans to redevelop the waterfront precinct, which has been under construction for the past year.

Although the redevelopment was widely supported, residents say they either did not expect a wall at all, or expected it to be much smaller.

A petition calling for more information about the wall was signed by many in the community. (Facebook: Jason Hart)

More than 300 people have signed a petition calling on the council to address their concerns, prompting Thursday's public meeting.

A member of the public has also parked a trailer with a large outdoor video screen on it, displaying humorous messages about the issue directed at the council.

An electronic billboard about "The Very Hungry Wall" was set up to protest the project. (Supplied: Scott Newett)

Professional cray fisher Jason Hart said he believed the wall's construction was causing safety issues at the port, which was used by commercial fishing boats and tourism vessels.

He said the construction had removed one of the vehicle entrances to the wharf, meaning trucks and tourists alike gathered in the same area.

"It's just a danger the way they've done it," he said.

" It's weird. A total waste of money. A near Berlin Wall, that's what it is. "

Cray fisher Jason Hart says the wall is a "waste of money". (Supplied)

Hope for progress after meeting

Resident Jo-Ann Kerr was at Thursday night's meeting but left still unsure why the wall had been built and what the council was going to do about it.

"I think the council agreed the wall needs to come down or be substantially renovated to make it a little bit more appealing," she said.

Strahan resident Jo-Ann Kerr says the council did appear to agree that change was needed. (Supplied)

"We're a little bit confused as to the reasons from council as to why it's there."

Scott Newett also attended the meeting and said he had never seen the community so united in opposition.

He said the council appeared receptive to their concerns.

"It was just a total majority of people that were on the same page that they don't like the wall, and they couldn't see the purpose of the wall," Mr Newett said.

" When you have an iconic view that visitors come down to see, you do have to question how we got here. "

Redevelopment planned since 2015

The redevelopment of the wharf has been in the works for more than a decade and attracted more than $3.3 million in state and federal funding.

On its website, the council said it would "create a modern, accessible public space that celebrates the existing area, making it a vibrant place for locals and visitors to connect".

It also said the project would create a new outdoor public space along the waterfront, renew the visitor centre, and relocate some public amenities and car parking.

Construction updates refer to a "shelter wall". (Supplied: West Coast Council)

Construction updates on the website refer to a "shelter wall", which also appears in a photo of the construction site highlighting progress on a large concrete wall.

Mr Newett said that the description made no sense, as the wall provided no shelter from the prevailing weather direction.

A 2015 document about the waterfront area discussing existing issues at the wharf refers to a wall, but only as a metaphor for how cruise boats block views when in port.

Council agrees to 'look at options'

The West Coast Council was asked what the purpose of the wall was, how it intended to respond to the community concerns, and whether the wall would potentially be removed or altered.

Mayor Shane Pitt says a report will be presented to the next council meeting. (ABC News: Sandy Powell)

In a statement, Mayor Shane Pitt on Friday said it had been built "on the advice of experts, including engineers and architects".

"The council has now agreed to look at options including potentially reducing its height if it assessed that the wall is required for retainment purposes," he said.

"A report will be presented to council's meeting on 27th January."

title: The Queensland town taking heat out of the global AI industry
text:
Gladstone is one of Queensland's industrial hubs, but now it is also playing a key role in the global AI industry as it pumps out a critical mineral needed to cool high-performance chips used by some of the world's biggest tech companies.

High performance chips inside data centres power AI and are used by the likes of the likes of NVIDA, Intel and Amazon.

But with high computing power comes increased heat that threatens to stall further growth.

To cool them, large modern data centres need powerful air conditioning systems as well as lots of water. Some large centres require up to 19 million litres per day of water, equivalent to the amount used by a town populated by 10,000 to 50,000 people.

Alpha HPA's processing plant aims to be at the cutting edge of the Ai revolution. (Supplied: Alpha HPA)

High-purity alumina produced by rapidly expanding Gladstone-based company Alpha HPA is used in modern chips, also known as semiconductors, to help conduct heat away from critical components.

Alpha HPA employs about 130 people and is building the world’s biggest production facility to refine high purity alumina, using chemicals from Orica and alumina feedstock from Rio Tinto.

It plans to almost double that workforce over the next year.

What is high purity alumina?

The white substance, which has the consistency of icing sugar, plays a critical role in drawing heat away from the chips that are powering AI, which is projected by UN Trade and Development to be multi-trillion dollar sector by the 2030s.

The competitive geopolitical battle for critical minerals like HPA has supercharged Alpha HPA's expansion, allowing it to attract millions of dollars in federal and state government funding and financing support.

Alpha HPA's high purity alumina pictured with a semiconductor. (Supplied: Alpha HPA)

Alpha HPA managing director Rob Williamson said HPA was poised to replace silica as a thermal management material in advanced chips, which he said could unlock a huge potential market.

"It's like an engine in your car, if it runs too hot, performance drops and components fail," he said.

"Computer chips are no different. There is an optimal operating temperature and once you exceed it, performance is impacted.”

QUT professor of technology management and strategy Robert Perrons said even several years ago, modern computer chips were generating more heat output per square unit of area than a steam iron.

Hundreds of millions of dollars announced in loans for critical minerals projects Critical minerals projects in Queensland and South Australia will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in federal government loans as part of the government's plan for a "future made in Australia".

"They've continued to get worse," Professor Perrons said.

"The number of calculations that we're asking these chips to perform is just getting astronomical. As a consequence, a lot of heat is generated.

"How to manage that excess heat has become an extremely important one in chip design. That’s where HPA comes into play because it is great at being an insulator and has much higher thermal conductivity."

Phineas Glover is head of APAC ESG and Sustainability at UBS, an investment bank which evaluates sectors and industries.

He said the growth of AI was pushing data centres and chips to their "physical limits".

"Heat is becoming a major constraint on computing performance," he said.

"We also will need to invest in advanced cooling equipment. But none of this is going to tackle the thermal bottleneck on its own."

Mr Glover said thermal inefficiency can lead to higher energy expenditure, greater cooling load and growing operational risk.

Alpha HPA managing director Rob Williamson says computer chips do not operate as well when their optimal temperature is exceeded. (Supplied; Alpha HPA)

He said the success of the technology would be a "positive development for Australia."

" The country already plays an important role in supplying materials for the energy transition and Al. "

"HPA represents a move downstream into high-specification, value-added materials that directly enable advanced technologies.”

UBS analyst Phineas Glover says the success of high purity alumina could be a positive development for Australia. (Supplied: UBS Securities)

Last year, Alpha HPA received $30 million from the Queensland Government's critical minerals and battery technology fund, provided through the Queensland Investment Corporation (QIC).

That followed a $400 million financing package from the Federal Government's Export Finance Australia and the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility.

The company has already commenced commercial sales to semi-conductor manufacturers in Asia and the US, with letters of intent to provide up to 4000 metric tonnes of HPA per annum.

The company started as a nickel miner in New South Wales after developing a process to extract HPA from ore but relocated to Gladstone in 2021 so it could access chemicals from Orica and feedstock from Rio Tinto to operate its proprietary technology.

title: 'Terrible job to cuddle baby wombats': Behind the scenes as a wildlife carer
text:
Wombat poo is famously cube-shaped, but over the past few days Lindy Butcher has discovered it can come in all shapes.

The two six-month old joeys she's caring for have had bouts of explosive diarrhoea, after coming into her care when their mothers were hit by cars.

They've been in perfect health for the past few months, but Ms Butcher puts the change in excrement down to the hot weather.

"Even with the air-con on they don't cope well with the heat," she said.

But it's far from the most challenging aspect of the role she's had to grapple with in the past 30 years as a wildlife carer.

"It's quite a possibility that they will die, so there's the worry that goes with it," she said.

"It can be soul crushing when you have losses.

"It can be the loss of an animal that you've only had for an hour, or it can be an animal that you've cared for for three months or for a year, and that can be really hard."

Lindy Butcher with six-month-old Digby the wombat. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

'Terrible job having to cuddle baby wombats'

At about six months old, the joeys would normally be very dependent on their mother, but Ms Butcher said, for now, they were very dependent on her.

"It's a terrible job having to cuddle baby wombats to make them feel happy. Honestly, a dreadful job," she joked.

Ms Butcher said the joeys needed to feel safe and, just like any other babies, wanted to go everywhere with their caregiver.

"I mean it's no hardship though to have a baby wombat with you when you go out to a friend's place for dinner. Nobody complains," she said.

Perks aside, Ms Butler said the real reason she began volunteering was to keep Australia's unique wildlife wild.

"Our volunteers are doing it so that people who live here in Canberra, who love having birds in their garden, echidnas wandering through, waking up to birdsong in the morning, can continue to be amazed by our wildlife and the government can continue to be seen as a government that values the role our wildlife plays socially, environmentally, economically," she said.

Wildlife carer Sharon releases Cindy the wombat back into the wild. (Supplied)

Reptiles 'easier than possums'

Mark Jenkins became a volunteer after finishing full-time work.

"I always knew I wanted to get into working with animals — something completely different from a public service desk job," he said.

While he'd always been intrigued by reptiles, he had no knowledge or experience in handling them. But, after some initial training, he started with rescues and transport work before gradually moving into hands-on animal care.

"I found reptiles, to be frank, easier than some of our more challenging animals like possums and birds," he said.

Mr Jenkins is now the reptile coordinator and treasurer with ACT Wildlife.

He's currently caring for a turtle who was hit by a car.

The animal is recovering with Mr Jenkins after a local vet stabilised the bridge of its shell with metal rods and mended the cracks with dental epoxy.

"It's a great job they've done," he said, adding that the female turtle had even been able to lay her eggs.

"So I'm set up to be a turtle dad again."

Mr Jenkins said even if Canberrans didn't want to become carers themselves, they should be aware of the environment they live, work and play in and understand the wildlife that's around them.

"So many of our reptiles come in who have been attacked by people's dogs, cats, garden implements and lawn mowers, as well as car accidents," he said.

"It's not as though we're bringing in animals that would be injured, in the way they are, from the wild. They're injured usually because of human activity.

"Humans have an obligation, I think, to be aware of that and to do what they can to help with their environment."

Vet Rachael Grigson and reptile carer Mark Jenkin examine a blue tongue lizard's injury. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

Peak rescue season

ACT Wildlife operates from an unassuming demountable building at Jerrabomberra Wetlands.

There are enclosures for animals awaiting care, a part-time wildlife vet surgery and a 24/7 call centre helpline that handles about 14,000 calls per year from concerned, and often distressed members of the public wanting to know how to help injured wildlife.

If an animal needs to come into care or requires treatment, there is a network of volunteer carers, with skills to deal with specific species, that are called on to help.

Summer is peak season for the organisation, with heat and holidays driving up both call volumes and the number of animal casualties.

Though Ms Butcher said demand for ACT Wildlife's services was increasing year-round, as Canberra's population grows and more homes are built.

"We are pushing them out of their habitats and environments," she said.

"Where are the animals going to go and who's going to provide homes and food for those animals?

"Those animals have a role to play in the environment, so we need volunteers to grow with that at the same time."

ACT Wildlife staff with rescued peewee magpie lark. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

Caring for the carers

Part-time wildlife veterinarian Rachael Grigson has a small clinic at the back on the ACT Wildlife office from where she administers care not only to the wildlife but also the carers.

"These carers are phenomenal — the work they do, the time they put, the patience," she said.

"I think the thing that people don't realise, and I didn't realise until I started working more with ACT Wildlife, is how much it's run by carers and volunteers that aren't getting paid and are just doing it 24/7."

Dr Grigson said when people called expecting instant responses, they often did not understand that volunteers were responding between their other life commitments.

She said looking after the dedicated carers was also a crucial part of looking after the wildlife.

"I think looking after carers is the most important thing, so we still have carers," she said.

More volunteers needed

Wildlife ACT operates out of an unassuming office as it seeks more volunteers to care for animals in need. (ABC News: Mark Moore)

There are about 40-50 active volunteer carers with ACT Wildlife along with a generous and supportive membership base, but more are always needed.

Ms Butcher said that there was a volunteer role to suit every stage of life, with training, mentoring and a community giving carers the skills and support they need.

But she added that the current cohort of volunteers were not getting any younger.

"We need to recruit young people who can see that they can fit this into their lives with their families," she said.

"I think for any anybody who volunteers anywhere you find a space for it in your life, and you build your life around that role.

"People say 'Oh, when I retire, I will.' Don't wait until you retire. You don't have to, we need you now."

title: Sabalenka defeats Keys in Australian Open final re-match
text:
Aryna Sabalenka says she is no longer thinking about last year's Australian Open final loss to Madison Keys after defeating the US star at the Brisbane International.

World number one Sabalenka found redemption with a 6-3, 6-3 triumph over Keys in their quarterfinal at Pat Rafter Arena on Friday.

Sabalenka will meet Karolína Muchová in the semifinals to continue her title defence in Brisbane, after the Czech had earlier defeated third seed Elena Rybakina.

A four-time major singles winner, Sabalenka dominated Keys with her first serve and made just three unforced errors to take the opening set.

A determined Keys recovered from match point down on her serve in the second set, but Sabalenka would not be denied and won in one hour and 29 minutes.

ABC Sport will have live coverage of the Australian Open from January 18.

Sabalenka has now claimed two straight-sets victories over world number seven Keys since losing last year's Australian Open final in three sets.

The 27-year-old steamrolled her American rival with a 6-0, 6-1 semifinal win at Indian Wells last year.

"I know that I lost in Australia against her and that's the big motivation, of course, to go out and to get the win," Sabalenka said.

"But I never stay in the past and never remember things from the previous meeting.

"I know that I have to be focused from the beginning until the end with her because she's an incredible fighter, and she can come back any time.

"When I won the match, of course, I was super happy, but I didn't really have the throwback to the Australian Open last year, to be honest."

Karolína Muchová ended Elena Rybakina's run in Brisbane. (Getty Images: Bradley Kanaris)

Muchová was the first to reach the semifinals in the women's draw after pulling off a 6-2, 2-6, 6-4 quarterfinal win over world number five Rybakina.

Elsewhere, Jessica Pegula beat Liudmila Samsonova 6-3, 7-6 (7/3) and will play in-form Marta Kostyuk in the semifinals.

Kostyuk backed up Thursday's straight-sets win over world number three Amanda Anisimova by upsetting teenage star Mirra Andreeva 7-6 (9/7), 6-3.

In the first of the men's quarterfinals, Aleksandar Kovacevic claimed a 7-6 (7/3), 4-6, 6-3 win over Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.

The American will next face compatriot Brandon Nakashima, who beat Raphaël Collignon 6-3, 6-3.

Alex Michelsen made it three Americans into the final four of the men's draw, beating compatriot Sebastian Korda 6-3, 7-6 (9/7).

He will play top seed Daniil Medvedev, who overcame impressive Polish lucky loser Kamil Majchrzak 6-7 (7/4), 6-3, 6-2 in the late Friday night match on Pat Rafter Arena.

AAP

title: Talc Alf's eccentric gallery a memorable stop in outback SA
text:
Amid the light brown sand and sparse scrub of outback South Australia, up springs Talc Alf's workshop, crafted using salvaged materials and emblazoned with the words "Reppublic [sic] University of Common Sense".

Alf sits at his workbench, picks up his tools and sets to work on a chunk of white stone.

His material of choice? The soft, powdery talc that he has been sourcing around Australia since a stint working with geologists in Bunbury — it is what has given him the nickname he has come to be known by both near and afar.

Armed with a suite of tools, Talc Alf sits down to carve his next piece. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

As Talc Alf takes to the stone with a rasp, clouds of white powder swirl into the hot air, coating everything in its path in a pale cast.

A few steps from his workbench and he is illuminated by the unforgiving outback sun that shines on his outdoor gallery.

Once the works are finished, they are placed on shelves for visitors to peruse. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

The carved talc sits outside on wood and rusty metal shelves exposed to the elements, with the very fringes of the Gammon Ranges peaking up on the horizon.

Talc Alf's home, gallery and workshop is located just off the Strzelecki Track near Lyndhurst, about 570 kilometres north of Adelaide, and has become a popular stop for tourists on the outback loop.

Alf's gallery is on the outskirts of Lyndhurst. (ABC News)

It was a long and windy road to Lyndhurst, though.

Alf's family immigrated to Australia from Holland when he was just eight years old.

His parents and four siblings hopped off the boat in Fremantle to make a new home in Australia, settling on a farm in Margaret River.

As an adult, he worked odd jobs across Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory, before settling near Lyndhurst in South Australia in 1974.

Whether it was cleaning water troughs on sheep stations or driving backhoes, Talc Alf has given it a spin. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

Along the way, he picked up a geology book that marked different talc deposits around the country.

Alf read an article on First Nations communities in Canada carving soapstone or talc, and was inspired to pick up the tools.

"I thought, maybe I'll do the same thing myself," he said.

"I was not too keen to stay on the farm for the rest of my life, so I just thought I'd make a living at this carving business."

Talc Alf credits a geology book for his knowledge of talc deposits around the country. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

It all starts with smoothing the super soft talc with sandpaper and a rasp, before picking a design.

"You draw the picture on. It's like doing a painting and then you get the hammer and chisel out and chip it out."

The supple mineral can be shaved down to a smooth surface. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

His talc creations often depict Australiana scenes from fiction, history and anecdotes from folks he has stumbled across in his travels through Australia.

"I'll get up every day and I [think] I gotta work out something there, and I if I read a good book about it, I'll get a bit of inspiration here or something like that," he said.

His works are often inspired by stories he stumbles across in books and country pubs. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

Talc Alf's gallery has now become an attraction for tourists and most days a bus of visitors will pull of the Strzelecki Track connecting Innamincka and Lyndhurst to see what the fuss is all about.

"They're fascinated … and some of them would come back after a few years.

"They said, 'We still got your carving sitting on the mantelpiece, been there for the last 20 years' or something and some bring their kids with them."

An empty chair lets visitors know Talc Alf is not in. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

While his white angular pieces are a focal point of the gallery, Talc Alf has also created his own interpretation of the Latin alphabet.

It started when he was teaching his daughter to read. He took her onto the light brown sand on their Lyndhurst property.

With a stick in hand, he drew a vertical line on the sandy ground before adding a circle at the top, describing what he was doing.

"You started with the letter P, you draw a stroke for the body and you put your head on top of it and put a little smile on and arms and legs — you got P for people," he said.

"That should be taught at schools. It's easy to do."

An ever-present cloud of white talc powder coats Talc Alf's hands. (ABC News: Isabella Carbone)

From there, Alf came up with visual explanations and an origin story for each letter in the alphabet and like a philosopher, he will happily wax lyrical about this interpretation.

"Every letter's a story and it didn't come from England, it came from all over the world, people bought in their ideas," he said.

Despite being in his 80s, Alf has no plans to put down the tools or close up shop anytime soon.

His eccentric gallery remains a memorable stop in South Australia's outback.

title: Aussies exit United Cup and Poland advances to semis
text:
Australia captain Lleyton Hewitt has not offered excuses following the host nation's loss to Poland in the United Cup quarterfinals.

After Poland's six-time major champion Iga Świątek thrashed Maya Joint 6-1, 6-1 in the opening singles rubber at Sydney's Ken Rosewall Arena, Alex de Minaur levelled the tie for Australia with a pulsating 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 victory over Hubert Hurkacz.

But Poland rebounded to win the deciding mixed doubles rubber, with Katarzyna Kawa and Jan Zieliński defeating Storm Hunter and John-Patrick Smith 6-4, 6-0.

Poland will face the United States in the semifinals.

ABC Sport will have live coverage of the Australian Open from January 18.

Hewitt did not regret resting de Minaur from the mixed doubles, as he wanted to manage the workload of the world number six ahead of the Australian Open, which begins on January 18.

"Alex was feeling a few tweaks the last few days and he's been doing a lot of training in the off-season to get ready for five-set matches," Hewitt said.

"We decided that the best thing for him, for his body moving forward, was not to put his hand up to play mixed tonight.

Joint gets Barty's backing ahead of Aus Open seeding Teenage star Maya Joint will be the first home women's seed at the Australian Open since former world number one Ash Barty broke a 44-year title drought in 2022.

"It is tough though, as well to make a decision so quickly, and also if you are that second match to turn around straight away and switch on.

"And you just don't want to risk injury as well and especially the amount of moving that he had to do tonight against a bloody quality player."

De Minaur delivered for his country in the singles with a tenacious performance against former Wimbledon semifinalist Hurkacz.

He was forced to dig deep to win the match, having fended off 10 of Hurkacz's 11 break-point chances in an epic encounter stretching two hours and 20 minutes.

"That's what it took," he said.

"I just had to fight him off from the first point to the last, a huge mental effort."

Former world number one Iga Świątek only conceded two games against Maya Joint. (Getty Images: Brendon Thorne)

Świątek had earlier overcome a mysterious meltdown to crush Joint in just 58 minutes to give Poland a 1-0 lead.

But the former world number one's victory was anything but straightforward.

The 24-year-old burst into tears at the opening changeover, despite breaking the Australian teenager in the third game for a 2-1 lead, only to return to the court and play on.

Świątek gave her courtside teammates a thumbs-up after gaining a double break for a 4-1 lead and barely lost a point in winning six games on the spin to seize the first set.

She won the second set in equally convincing fashion.

Poland will meet the US in their semifinal on Saturday evening.

Belgium and Switzerland will contest the first semifinal earlier in the day.

AAP

title: English is Toki's second language, but he sings in a classic Elvis drawl
text:
While English is not Toki Toyokazu's first language, it has not stopped him from stepping into Elvis Presley's iconic blue suede shoes.

Hailing from Aomori, Japan, the tribute artist has travelled around the world performing hits from the "King of Rock and Roll".

Mr Toyokazu is part of a growing international presence at the Parkes Elvis Festival.

"Singing his songs, [it] makes me friends with people all over the world — no-one is loved as much as he is," he said.

Loading...

"I love it here; it has given me a lot of love."

The Parkes Elvis Festival attracts about 25,000 visitors to the town of about 10,000 people.

The festival is held annually in the second week of January to coincide with Elvis's birthday.

Elvis in Spanish

English is not the first language of busker Rita Marquez either, who grew up in Colombia hearing Elvis's songs in Spanish.

Ms Marquez has travelled to the festival for the first time with friends from her home in Gladstone, Queensland.

Rita Marquez says the translated version of Blue Suede Shoes became very popular in South America when she was growing up. (ABC News: Lani Oataway)

She said Elvis's appeal transcends cultures.

"Elvis is a spirit; the legend that he left is for everybody — for young people, women and men," she said.

" It's a legacy that we receive and share. "

She said Elvis's tunes translated literally into her native tongue, which made them easy to sing in both languages.

Up to 28,000 people are expected to attend the Parkes Elvis Festival. (ABC News: Lani Oataway)

A female Elvis

Sydney's Maria Phillips started singing from the age of three because of Elvis.

The "Platinum Elvis" tribute artist remembers watching his movies on repeat at her grandmother's house as a child.

"I stood in front of the TV and did Elvis," she said.

Maria Phillips is a tribute artist at this year's Parkes Elvis Festival. (ABC News: Lani Oataway)

That moment sparked a trajectory that brought Ms Phillips to the Parkes Elvis Festival as one of a few female musicians embodying The King.

"I think I've sung an Elvis song every day of my life since I was three," she said.

Ms Phillips sings in the same key as Elvis, but said she does not attempt to replicate his voice.

"I think as a woman, if you can bring your perspective … and channel it yourself in your way, why not?

"I hope [Elvis] would be looking down on us grateful that he's not limiting himself to half the population," she said.

The 2026 event celebrates 70 years since the release of Elvis's "Love Me Tender" movie. (ABC News: Lani Oataway)

Erica Gahan and her two sisters "all love Elvis" after being introduced to his music by their parents.

Attending the festival for the first time, they are part of a growing number of women who participate in the busking competition.

Erica Gahan busking at the Parkes Elvis Festival in 2026. (ABC News: Lani Oataway)

"Usually we only perform for our parents in the lounge room, so it is really special," Ms Gahan said.

"It's really nice to be part of that [Elvis] community, it makes us feel less eccentric."

While Ms Gahan did not see herself on the main stage anytime soon, she was "really proud" of women like Maria Phillips.

title: NSW SES to allow people to volunteer for a day when disaster strikes
text:
The New South Wales State Emergency Service (SES) has moved to embrace "volunteers for a day" to boost its ability to tackle an increasing number of natural disasters.

The spontaneously formed, community-led "mud army" has become synonymous with flood and storm recovery efforts since its inception during the 2011 Brisbane floods.

Now the NSW SES has moved to harness the people power of mud armies differently.

During the record-breaking flooding that hit the NSW Mid North Coast in May last year, the SES partnered with the MidCoast Community Flood Response (MCCFR) mud army to respond to the disaster together.

The May 2025 floods in the Manning Valley broke records. (ABC News)

In a first-of-its-kind operation, the SES provided training, personal protective gear and insurance to more than 1,200 people wanting to volunteer for short periods.

"We've seen these types of spontaneous mobilisation of the community during major disasters," NSW SES executive Andrew McCullough said.

" But what separated this event was that partnership with the SES to make the response so much more efficient and effective. "

More than 1,200 volunteers joined the MidCoast Community Flood Response mud army during the May 2025 floods. (ABC Mid North Coast: Claire Simmonds)

The mud army helpers were led by trained SES volunteers to clean out mud and debris from flooded homes.

A group of seven friends gathered to form the MCCFR, creating social media accounts to call for volunteers and support.

Sophie Curtis said she felt compelled to do more for her community and joined SES Forster-Pacific Palms after the May 2025 floods. (ABC Mid North Coast: Claire Simmonds)

Organiser Sophie Curtis managed the operations of the mud army until the SES partnership began.

"It was truly incredible seeing them really come together; they gave us so much spirit," she said.

Japanese social welfare organisations run volunteer centres to support citizens mobilising at disaster sites. (ABC News: Fletcher Yeung)

Tsunami-inspired

Setting up community volunteer hubs was a Japanese idea that the SES adopted after Mr McCullough toured world disaster sites on a Churchill Fellowship in 2024.

"The coordination in Japan, using social welfare councils to bring people together to coordinate teams and to send people out safely to do jobs, is what we've brought back to SES," he said.

Andrew McCullough's tour of disaster sites helped develop NSW SES spontaneous volunteering plans. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Mr McCullough flew to the country to learn about the response to the Fukushima nuclear power plant disaster in 2011.

He also visited areas affected by earthquakes, such as Türkiye and Christchurch, parts of Chile devastated by wildfires, and New York to study the city's response to the 9/11 terror attack.

Mr McCullough said communities stepped in to lead responses to these disasters — usually through social media — when a government could not provide the level of assistance needed.

"People can connect online and start these volunteering groups, we've seen this overseas, and this is what happened in Taree where the Mid Coast Community group connected together via social media."

Mike Wassing says the the onboarding process has been streamlined to enable volunteers to join units faster. (ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)

Volunteer boom

NSW SES commissioner Mike Wassing said many of the Mid North Coast's mud army members were among the "extraordinary" 500 people who applied to become permanent members of the SES in the aftermath of the floods.

"We do normally see a bit of a spike in interest in terms of new members coming into the organisation post a disaster, which is tremendous," he said.

"We know from research that local members who are involved in the operations during the response — but also in the earlier parts of recovery — recover quicker, better, and there are fewer mental health [problems]," he said.

For the past decade, researchers have urged disaster response agencies to harness people who come forward in times of disasters.

Disaster capacity researcher Blythe McLennan says volunteering rates are not declining, but there is a shift to less formalised volunteering. (ABC Melbourne: Billy Draper)

Australian Institute for Disaster Resilience manager Blythe McLennan said volunteering rates were not declining.

"I'd say one of the key trends we're seeing is a shift away from longer-term, high-commitment volunteering towards shorter, more episodic volunteering and more flexible ways of volunteering," she said.

"What I love about the example in Taree is how it's brought together the strengths of the SES and the community mobilisation to create a more effective response for communities, so it's a surge capability for the SES."

MCCFR volunteers march into Wingham after the record-breaking Manning Valley floods. (ABC Mid North Coast: Claire Simmonds)

Mr McCullough believes partnering with community groups and offering spontaneous volunteering hubs will be a focus for future disasters.

"We see New South Wales as a state of six million people where almost everyone could be a disaster volunteer in the future," he said.

Brodie Mayer and Sophie Curtis founded a disaster response group and have now joined the SES. (ABC Mid North Coast: Claire Simmonds)

Ms Curtis and her partner Brodie Mayer's experience with the SES during the Mid-North Coast flood response prompted them to sign up as full-time members at the Forster-Pacific Palms SES unit.

"I just felt as though that I had more skills to offer and I wanted to formally be involved, not just when there's a crisis," Ms Curtis said.

" There's pretty much not a week that goes by without our unit responding to calls for help in the community, so we love it. "

title: Barmy Army turns Ashes defeat into Australian tourism win
text:
It may have been a disappointing Ashes tour for the England cricket team but it wasn't the case for the travelling English supporters, led by the Barmy Army.

It would be easy to imagine after watching their side lose the Ashes in 11 days, many of them would have packed up and headed home.

You would have thought wrong.

With over 35,000 British visitors making their way to Australia for the series, they have not only provided a boost to the atmosphere at the grounds, but to the local economy.

This has been the biggest tour for the Barmy Army in Australia since they first started. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

The Barmy Army was founded by two friends for the 1994/95 Ashes in Australia, originally designed as an informal supporter group celebrating the English team.

It has grown to become one of the largest and most recognisable fan groups in all of global sport.

And it is a business that employs staff to deliver different touring packages, and sell merchandise.

"We have had over 3,000 clients come over here to enjoy the cricket, some have come for seven weeks and some have come for the last week … they've loved all the major cities," Barmy Army staff member Neil said.

Gary from Cornwall has been part of the travelling supporter base, and says it's been well worth it to join the tour.

"It's my first time with the Barmy Army, it's a cracking experience. You certainly learn to drink and sing with them," he said.

Despite Australia's on-field dominance, visitors continued their travels and made their presence felt across a range of businesses, from hotels and restaurants to retail and entertainment.

English supporters during the A-League game between Perth Glory and Melbourne City at Melbourne Rectangular Stadium. (AAP Image: Joel Carrett)

Tim Harcourt, the chief economist at the University of Technology Sydney’s Centre for Sport, said many parts of the country enjoyed the benefits.

"Many of them take camper vans and travel around Australia so I think it really helps not just the cities where the Tests are but also regional Australia," he said.

"If you are going to go to the Test like a lot of them are, then that means there's more of a chance to help local businesses which have nothing to do with cricket whatsoever. I think the pubs are doing especially well."

Cricket Australia had estimated losses of up to $30 million from the two-day Perth and Melbourne Tests, but it provided a unique opportunity for Australia's economy.

"The cricket fans are spending so much money, obviously they are on holiday and adoring the cricket. I think Australia is one of our favourite destinations to come to as well," Barmy Army merchandising staff member Beccy said.

"Regardless of what is going on in the cricket, everybody is singing, chanting and also creating new songs as we go.”

The Boxing Day Test also helped local codes, with a contingent of the Barmy Army making their voices heard at two A-League Men fixtures and stealing the show with their trademark chants.

Between September 2024 -2025, UK travellers contributed $2 billion to the Australian economy. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

It was a massive year of sport throughout Australia in 2025, and it was enjoyed and appreciated by British travellers.

The British and Irish Lions tour saw a 72 per cent increase in UK visitors in July, and there are estimates that cricket fans have injected hundreds of millions of dollars into the Australian economy over the summer.

It may not have gone the way the Brits would have liked with the Ashes, but there is no doubt Australia will see them again when the next major sporting event rolls around.

title: Live: Trio missing in Victorian fires found safe, as heatwave intensifies across NSW
text:
Victoria's Emergency Management Commissioner Tim Wiebusch says at least 130 structures have been destroyed in bushfires across Victoria, but says that's a conservative figure and may rise.

He describes them as structures rather than homes.

He says the most have been in the Ravenswood and Harcourt fires, where at least 50 structures have been destroyed.

He says people should not return to areas that have been burnt until authorities say so.

"We don't want tourists, we don't want visitors, we want people to stay safe."

Wiebusch says assessments continue for the Longwood fire but 30 structures have been confirmed lost.

He says cropping land, a significant number of livestock and vineyards are also gone.

Meanwhile, a grassfire at Natimuk in Victoria's west has destroyed at least 20 structures and resulted in significant livestock losses.

Wiebusch says 10 structures are gone to a fire at Yarroweyah near Cobram.

title: The Korean Wave may splash back into China amid thawing ties
text:
Relations are warming between Beijing and Seoul under South Korea's left-leaning president, Lee Jae Myung.

A high-profile trip to Beijing last weekend was the second meeting between Mr Lee and Chinese President Xi Jinping in less than three months.

The pair took smiley selfies together on a Chinese Xiaomi smartphone gifted to Mr Lee at their last meeting.

The summit raised hopes in South Korea that improved ties would lead to the lifting of wide-ranging restrictions on the country's pop culture in China.

South Korean singer PSY and Rose, a member of K-pop group Blackpink, performing in Incheon last year. (AP: Ahn Young-joon)

Beijing imposed the de facto ban in 2016 after the US announced it would deploy a Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (THAAD) anti-missile system to South Korea. The THAAD is aimed at defending the country from China's ally North Korea.

Since then, South Korean artists have been barred from lucrative tours in China.

Chinese authorities imposed limits on the screening of South Korean films and of its celebrities appearing in advertisements or other broadcasts.

The relationship between the East Asian neighbours further deteriorated under right-wing president Yoon Suk Yeol, who now faces a raft of criminal charges after he briefly imposed martial law in 2024.

Yet over the weekend, the governments of Mr Lee and Mr Xi signed US$44 million ($65.8 million) worth of trade deals and dozens of memorandums of understandings.

On Chinese social media platform Weibo, one user asked: "Does this mean the Korean Wave can come back into China?"

Hallyu as successful soft diplomacy

The Korean Wave, or hallyu, refers to the stratospheric rise in global popularity of Korean popular culture since the 1990s — promoted by an explicit soft power strategy from Seoul.

The 'quirkiness and subtle darkness' of Korean books captivate Australians While K-lit might seem a world apart from its glitzy juggernaut cousin K-pop, its growing number of Australian fans say it is a thoughtful way to engage with Korean culture.

Its success is undeniable.

Squid Game is Netflix's most-streamed non-English language series of all time.

The Korean film Parasite became the first foreign-language film to win Best Picture at the Oscars in 2020.

Korean girl group Blackpink are the most-streamed female band on Spotify.

"Its role in reshaping global perceptions of South Korea has been immense," said Sarah Keith, a media lecturer and expert on K-pop at Macquarie University.

Sarah Keith says China overturning the Korean culture ban would be a huge win for President Lee Jae Myung. (Supplied)

"K-pop and K-drama are both powerful instruments of soft power, and may make Chinese consumers more likely to prefer Korean products," Dr Keith said.

" K-pop idols are strong promoters for many types of Korean goods, whether fashion, beauty, food, or tourism. "

The Beijing office of the Korea Creative Content Agency, a government body associated with South Korea's cultural ministry, reported last year that "in China, no Korean dramas have aired since March 2023".

"Since early 2024, even the airing of Chinese remakes of Korean dramas has been implicitly restricted," it said.

Still, Chinese consumers are able to access Korean dramas, film and music online by using a VPN.

Netflix says Squid Game is the most viewed non-English series in its history. (Supplied: Youngkyu Park/Netflix)

The 2025 Overseas Hallyu Survey found the average Chinese person surveyed was spending more than 15 hours a month consuming Korean cultural products — around three times longer than respondents in Japan.

The survey, conducted annually by the Korean Foundation for International Cultural Exchange, found about a quarter of Chinese respondents had seen a Korean film in the past month.

Ban to be 'resolved gradually', says Lee

After the weekend's leaders' summit in Beijing, Korean officials said China maintained no such ban exists.

"China maintains that it does not recognise the policy as formally existing," Korean national security advisor Wi Sung-lac told reporters, as quoted by The Korea Times.

"In today's dialogue, there were comments questioning whether it was even necessary to debate its existence," he said.

"That makes it difficult to characterise the situation as entering a clear lifting phase."

Instead, the two countries agreed to less politically contested cultural exchanges, including in sport.

South Korea's skincare innovation attracts shoppers and Australian brands Once considered niche, K-beauty products are now everywhere — from luxury department stores to local pharmacies and even supermarkets.

President Lee was quoted by Korean media as saying the issue would be "resolved gradually, step by step".

According to Mr Lee, his Chinese counterpart, Mr Xi, likened the situation to the process of ice melting or ripe fruit falling from a tree.

And there have already been signs of thawing.

Despite a number of K-pop concerts being cancelled in China last year, the Korean hip hop group Homies managed to play a concert in the Chinese city of Wuhan in April.

After a bilateral summit in November, Kim Young-bae from South Korea's ruling Democratic Party said Mr Xi "responded positively" to the idea of a major K-pop performance taking place in Beijing.

Korean rap group Homies played their first-ever show in China in April 2025. (Supplied)

State media reported the top destination on the Chinese travel booking site Qunar at the beginning of 2026 was Seoul.

Macquarie University's Dr Keith said a full lift of the Hallyu ban would be a major domestic political victory for Mr Lee.

It would boost economic confidence in South Korea, especially in sectors particularly reliant on China such as the semiconductor industry, she said.

title: Elon Musk limits X's AI image generator over non-consensual sexual imagery
text:
Australian users of Elon Musk's X platform are speaking out about non-consensual sexual images of themselves being generated by its artificial intelligence bot Grok at the request of other users.

Grok is a large language model AI bot that has been promoted by X as having fewer safeguards than its competitors.

In recent days, the bot and X have come under fire, after users started prompting Grok to digitally undress users on X — mostly women — without their consent.

Loading...

One Australian victim, who goes by Ele online, says she was targeted after she posted on the platform that she did not consent.

The ABC has decided not to identify Ele or to share the images created of her, to protect her privacy.

"As soon as I explicitly said that I did not consent and I was not with it, it somehow enraged a bunch of men, who … decided to generate said images," Ele told triple j hack.

"There was one … who generated an image of me in a burqa.

" There was another who … turned my shirt into a bikini, then to a micro bikini, then to dental floss, and then — to get around Grok's safety features — asked it to cover me in doughnut glaze, which it did. "

A grok prompt used against Australian erotic model Ele. (Source: X)

Ele is a content creator who posts non-nude sexual content on X and on paid subscription sites.

When she spoke out about the AI-generated fake images on X, some other users told her she should not complain because of the type of photos she had already posted on the site.

"I think it's the exact same as telling a woman she shouldn't drink if she doesn't want to be sexually assaulted," Ele told hack.

"Like, yes, this is a risk that is involved with doing a certain type of work, but it shouldn't happen.

"And I think the men saying that are definitely trying to cover and hide from accountability."

Ele posted on X after Grok created fake images of her without her consent. (Supplied.)

Ele is not alone in being targeted by users on X.

American analytics firm Copyleaks estimated Grok generated roughly one non-consensual sexual image every minute in the 48 hours to December 31.

A separate analysis of Grok requests and posts by European non-profit AI Forensics suggested more than half the images created by Grok contained people in "minimal attire", and that 81 per cent of the images were of women.

The group says it analysed 20,000 Grok-generated images and 50,000 user requests, and found that 2 per cent of the posts appeared to depict people under the age of 18.

In Australia, the ABC has seen Grok-generated undressed images of at least four Australian politicians.

AI abuse 'no surprise'

Dr Joel Scalan, who is a senior lecturer at the Child Sexual Abuse Material Deterrence Centre at the University of Tasmania, says AI companies appear to be bypassing safeguards in the pursuit of profits.

Dr Joel Scanlan says AI companies are abandoning safeguards to try and attract more users. (ABC News: Scott Ross)

He said the issues being raised by X users about Grok were not surprising.

"We have a culture in tech companies of 'move fast and break things,'" Dr Scanlan told triple j hack.

"That's the label they came up with 20 years ago, and it's still very much the case.

"In the context of AI … anything that they can get into the press to get their platform out there is seen as a bit of a positive.

" It's profit over protection … [Elon Musk] sees it as being, 'hey, it's free speech, let's just use the tools in any way that we can', however, that doesn't mean there's no societal impact. "

Musk continues to promote AI tool

X owner Elon Musk addressed concerns about illegal content on the platform in a post earlier this week.

In the post, he wrote that anyone who used Grok to create illegal content would be punished.

But since Musk's post, the bot has continued to respond to prompts requesting it to undress women, and in some cases, children.

The ABC contacted xAI about Grok to ask whether more safeguards would be put in place to protect users, and received what appeared to be an auto-reply: "Legacy Media Lies."

On Friday, the AI bot began denying user requests for altered images.

It posted that the image generator had been limited to paying subscribers due to concerns about non-consensual sexual imagery.

Governments from France and India to the UK have condemned the use of Grok to "undress" women without their consent, with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer calling it a "disgrace" and the country's independent communications regulator saying it had made contact with X and xAI about the issue.

In Australia, a spokesperson for the eSafety Commissioner said eSafety had "received reporting relating to the use of Grok to generate sexualised images of adults and children".

The spokesperson said while some reports were still being assessed, reports of child exploitation material did not "meet the classification for threshold for class 1 material" and so no takedown notices had been issued.

"eSafety remains concerned about the increasing use of generative AI to sexualise or exploit people, particularly where children are involved," the spokesperson said.

Can generative AI ever be safe?

For Australian X users like Ele, the non-consensual images are a sign that X needs to do more to protect its users.

Ele says she would like X to give account holders the option to opt out of having their images manipulated by AI.

"There should be a very strict feature to allow people to opt out … I do not believe if a person is detected by the AI, that the AI should be able to do anything with that," she told hack.

"The platforms should make sure it is not possible unless the person turns on that feature."

At the University of Tasmania, Dr Scanlan said that while it would be technically challenging for companies to offer an opt-out solution, there were other mitigating steps they could take.

"Large language models are great at understanding the intent of people and what they're asking.

title: Victoria Bushfires LIVE: 36 fires rage as State of Disaster declared; Family missing and homes razed
text:
A wind change likely to sweep across the Longwood fire ground in Victoria’s north-east today concerns Mansfield mayor Steve Rabie.

Fire authorities are continuing to monitor the Longwood blaze, with fears the popular holiday spot of Bonnie Doon could enter the firing line if Saturday’s strong winds alter the bushfire’s direction.

People are seen gathered at the Mansfield relief centre on Saturday. Credit: Luis Ascui

Rabie’s been at the Mansfield relief centre at the local recreation centre this morning, and is trying to reassure his community ahead of an expectedly smoky day ahead.

“The wind will turn around to the west, and we will be impacted by smoke,” Rabie said.

“People will get very nervous and worried, and that’s where our messaging has to come out. We understand you’re going to get smoke, it will get hazy and it might get uncomfortable.

“Get inside. Turn your air conditioner on if you have to, and wear a mask if you have to.”

“We’ve been practicing those plans, and now the plans have come to fruition. And it’s working extremely well.”

title: Melbourne nightclub irked as council workers captured removing 10¢ bottles from bins
text:
Council workers have irked a Melbourne nightclub by removing bottles and cans eligible for 10¢ refunds from their bins.

CCTV footage captured last year shows two men in high-vis vests collecting items from skips in Geddes Lane – behind King Street nightclub Inflation – and stashing them in a City of Melbourne truck.

Inflation owner Martha Tsamis said the popularity of Victoria’s container deposit scheme meant people often went through the venue’s recycling for empty drinks containers, which her business set aside to claim refunds for.

“We take time with staff to separate the bottles from rubbish, only to find that council workers are stealing from us, while being paid by the council and using a council vehicle,” she said.

title: Best-selling Australian author Trent Dalton withdraws from Adelaide Writers’ Week
text:
One of Australia’s best-selling authors has joined dozens of writers in withdrawing from Adelaide Writers’ Week following the Adelaide Festival board’s decision to remove Palestinian-Australian writer Dr Randa Abdel-Fattah from the line-up.

Trent Dalton, the author of novels including the 2018 smash hit Boy Swallows Universe, confirmed to this masthead on Saturday that he would not take part in the literary festival, but did not offer further comment.

Boy Swallows Universe author Trent Dalton. Credit: Jamila Toderas

The Adelaide Festival board said on Thursday that, while it was not suggesting “in any way” that Abdel-Fattah or her writing had any connection with the deadly terrorist attack at Bondi in December, given her past statements “it would not be culturally sensitive to continue to program her at this unprecedented time so soon after Bondi”.

When asked on Saturday if the writers’ week would go ahead, and how many authors had now pulled out, an Adelaide Festival spokeswoman declined to comment. Dalton’s publisher was also contacted for comment.

title: Heritage-listed Woolloongabba hotel goes up in flames for third time
text:
The Broadway Hotel in Woolloongabba went up in flames for a third time on Friday night, months after a development application was lodged to incorporate the derelict building into a 34-storey tower.

The 136-year-old hotel on Logan Road was reported alight about 11.40pm, with fire spreading from the ground floor up.

Footage taken by local Sarah Moran shows the fire burning in the front of the building at ground level, as firefighters worked to put it out.

Five fire crews attended the blaze, which was extinguished by 12.30am.

title: Starc, Head and Carey were outstanding, but they weren’t why Australia hammered England
text:
The problem with my Best Combined XI from the 2025-26 Ashes is that it only has VI players in it.

Travis Head opens the batting, and then we have Steve Smith as captain coming in at No.4. Alex Carey keeps wicket and bats six. The fast bowlers are Mitchell Starc, Scott Boland and Michael Neser. That’s almost a good indoor cricket team.

I hesitate to add more. There is too great a risk of choosing batsmen who accumulated runs but had minimal impact on the result (Joe Root, Harry Brook, Zak Crawley, Jacob Bethell). And if we include the next-best bowler (Ben Stokes or Josh Tongue, take your pick), we end up with the truly horrifying and morally unconscionable outcome of having more Englishmen than Australians in that hypothetical XI. Which would make me about as competent a selector as England’s.

The top-heavy nature of the contributions has been held out as proof that this was a low-quality Ashes series. I don’t agree that it was.

title: Brendon McCullum’s latest absurd claim should spell the end of his tenure
text:
An alarming sign of Brendon McCullum’s attitude to coaching England came on the Adelaide outfield, where, with Australian players uncorking the champagne behind him and the urn surrendered in record-equalling time, he made his soaring pitch to keep his job. “It’s a pretty good gig, it’s good fun,” he shrugged. “You travel the world with the lads and try to play some exciting cricket and achieve some things.”

He sounded as if he were describing life on board a cruise ship, where the pursuit of sporting glory was just some trifling distraction from the boys-on-tour vibe. And in return, he expected to keep a minimum £500,000-a-year ($1 million) salary, with zero accountability.

‘It’s a pretty good gig’: Brendon McCullum in Adelaide after England’s defeat left them 3-0 down in the Ashes. Credit: Getty Images

Any serious organisation would be disabusing him of this delusion today. But the message from the England and Wales Cricket Board is that it is still on board with Baz, that Baz is capable of cultural evolution, that there will simply be a few quiet, behind-the-scenes tweaks before the grand unveiling of Bazball 2.0. Until the past 24 hours, this position might just have been tenable.

Not now, though. Not after the exposure of a culture so dismally amateurish that Harry Brook, the white-ball captain, felt at liberty on the night before a one-day international against New Zealand to go to a nightclub, with that bone-headed decision leading to him being punched by a bouncer.

title: Medical episode theory in horror crash that put two girls in hospital
text:
A truck driver who crashed into four cars may have suffered a medical episode, emergency services said.

One of the cars, with a mother and two young girls inside, was pinned to a construction site after being rear-ended.

The girls – Ineza, 3, and one-year-old Itahe – were travelling with their mother, identified as Denyse, when a truck crashed into their vehicle about 11.45am on Thursday on Banya Avenue in Banya, south-west of Caloundra.

The three-year-old suffered critical head and chest injuries and was flown by helicopter to Queensland Children’s Hospital.

title: 'We need to adapt': Heatwaves are dividing cities and 'amplifying' vulnerability
text:
Parts of the country have been sweltering through a heatwave that's set to continue in Sydney this weekend, with temperatures of around 42C expected on Saturday.





But urban heat is not distributed equally. In some parts of Sydney — particularly the western suburbs, where temperatures during heatwaves can be several degrees higher than in the east — the forecast for Saturday is even warmer.





The impacts of heat inequality are exacerbated during a heatwave. So why do some suburbs experience that heat more acutely, and can anything be done about it?



Why is it hotter in some suburbs than others?

While western Sydney is frequently cited as an example of geographical heat inequality, similar dynamics can be observed in other parts of the country, such as Melbourne and Adelaide, with inland suburbs experiencing heatwaves more intensely than their coastal counterparts.



Riccardo Paolini is an associate professor at UNSW's School of Built Environment. He said a combination of factors leads to some parts of a city being more vulnerable to heat than others.





In Sydney's case, he said the primary factor driving higher temperatures in the west compared to the coast during heatwaves was advection, hot air flowing from inland areas, blocking cooling sea breezes from reaching western suburbs.





"During a heat wave, this hot front penetrates farther and farther, up to the inner west, and therefore you have a greater prevalence of the heat wave over the western suburbs," he told SBS News.





This is compounded by the 'urban heat island' effect, in which urban areas are significantly warmer than rural areas due to the high density of hard surfaces, like buildings and roads that retain more heat than greener spaces.





These include pavements made of asphalt and concrete and dark roofing on houses and other buildings, combined with insufficient vegetation, green space and shade, particularly around homes.





"These very, very dark surfaces heat the air like the bottom of a pot heats the water when you're cooking pasta," Paolini said.



Why does it matter?

This increased vulnerability can have varied and significant effects on the individual and broader society, and can overlap with populations that experience socio-economic disadvantage, such as western Sydney.





Ollie Jay is a professor of heat and health at the University of Sydney.





He told SBS News that while there are areas that get hotter temperatures, often amplified by the built environment, it's also important to consider populations with higher vulnerability.





"So you've got people there that are more vulnerable to that level of heat stress," he said.





"People who are older, people who have a chronic disease, often people who don't have access to air conditioning, or all three of those things put together."



LISTEN TO Nearly seven million Australians at risk from urban fires, new report warns SBS News 04:39 English

According to advocacy group Sweltering Cities, renters and low-income households are more likely to live in homes that don't provide good natural insulation or cooling, nor have access to cooling options such as air conditioning.





"A lot of people who are most vulnerable to the heat actually don't have access to air conditioning," Jay said.





Paolini said there was a correlation between high outdoor temperatures and physical activity, and that at a certain threshold, people simply stay at home or other indoor spaces that are cool.





"There's the effects of spending more money for electricity, bills for those who have air conditioning," he said.





"There's the sleep divide between coastal areas and inland areas, where people living in western suburbs have poorer sleep quality because of extreme heat during this period.





"It's getting worse over time."





One of the ways heat inequality is most acutely felt is when it comes to health.





"If we just think about the hospital cases [during a heatwave], both mortality and morbidity, then what we really see is that all of those numbers are massively amplified in people who are elderly … and people who have chronic diseases such as heart disease, kidney disease," Jay said.



READ MORE The reality virtually no Aussie can escape when a heatwave hits

Jay pointed out that beyond heat-related deaths, there were many other negative impacts below the surface when it came to negative health outcomes.





"You've got these other things that are happening inside the body when you get hot. It's not just your high body temperature. It's the fact that your heart has to work a lot harder to keep cool when you're exposed to the heat," he said.





"If you've got heart disease, that makes you much more susceptible to a heart attack. If you've got kidney disease, you're at much greater risk of kidney failure if you have dehydration. It's really quite complex and deep, broad impacts on human health and wellbeing across the lifespan."





As it stands, urban heat equality is set to intensify as the effects of climate change become more severe — with ocean temperatures continually rising and even less cooling sea breezes.





Paolini said Australian heatwaves are starting to more closely resemble those in Europe, which have excess heat-related mortality during extended heatwaves.





"So they don't have [temperatures of] 48C, as in Penrith, but they have eight days in a row when the night temperature doesn't drop below 28C or 30C, or even 32C in some cities. If you don't have air conditioning, this means that you cannot sleep, and then people who already have pre-existing medical conditions are exposed," he said.





"It's looking to a not-so-nice future for us, because urbanisation is increasing, density is increasing. With poor planning, that's where we are headed."



What can be done?

In Sydney’s west, there's been a growing push to plant more trees and increase tree canopy coverage to combat the urban heat island effect and reduce the impact of heatwaves.





Paolini said that while councils have focused on increasing the targets for tree canopy coverage, "in reality it's decreasing, because a lot of new developments, these urban sprawl developments, they chop off every tree and then they put out a few broomsticks without any room for the roots to grow".





"After 10 years, the tree is still a broomstick," Paolini said. "This means that the tree is not casting shadow over the street, and this means that the asphalt is absorbing a lot of solar radiation that then is dissipated by convection, so warming up there ... People want bigger houses, and this is eating up the space for the tree roots. That's a reality."





More broadly, Paolini pointed to projects like the Greater Sydney Heat Smart City Plan — led by council and contributed to by several research groups — aiming to mitigate extreme heat impacts across the region.





However, he said a lot of governance structures are fragmented, despite the problem being regional.





"So even if you put all your best landscaping and all the best urban planning in one council area, it will improve the situation, but it's like operating the air conditioning with the windows open."



Paolini said positive steps included a decrease in dark roofing as, since 2022, the National Construction Code included provisions for a minimum level of solar reflectance for new houses built. There's also a maximum solar absorptance — the amount of solar heat a roof takes in — of 64 per cent for new housing.





"It's a good start. The problem is, what do we do with what has already been built over the previous 50 years?"





Jay said it was vital that steps be taken to mitigate the "steady march" of climate change, such as decarbonising the economy and committing to the end of mass fossil fuel use.





"There's warming that's baked into the climate system that we're going to feel the effects for the next 30 years, at least, even if we were to stop using fossil fuels today," he said.





"So we've got to think about how we adapt.





“We can think about the way that buildings are built, making sure there's better glazing, there's fans installed, that you haven't got direct sunlight coming in. Better exterior blinds, better insulation in walls and roofs. These are the types of adaptations that reduce the amount of heat that gets into the indoor environment from the hot weather outside.”
